abstract: We explore a Leviathan analogy between neurons in a brain and human beings in society, asking ourselves whether individual intelligence is necessary for collective intelligence to emerge and, most importantly, what sort of individual intelligence is conducive of greater collective intelligence. We first review disparate insights from connectionist cognitive science, agent-based modeling, group psychology, economics and physics. Subsequently, we apply these insights to the sort and degrees of intelligence that in the Lotka-Volterra model lead to either co-existence or global extinction of predators and preys. We find several individual behaviors -- particularly of predators -- that are conducive to co-existence, eventually with oscillations around an equilibrium. However, we also find that if both preys and predators are sufficiently intelligent to extrapolate one other's behavior, co-existence comes along with indefinite growth of both populations. Since the Lotka-Volterra model is also interpreted to represent the business cycle, we understand this finding as a condition for economic growth around oscillations. Specifically, we hypothesize that pre-modern societies may not have exhibited limitless growth also because capitalistic future-oriented thinking based on saving and investing concerned at most a fraction of the population.
